contentrichtext.text: [[Image:Iapyx removing arrowhead from Aeneas.jpg|thumb|right|300px|<center>Iapyx removing an arrowhead from the leg of [[Aeneas]], with Aeneas's son, Ascanius (or Iulus), crying beside him.</center>]] In [[Greek mythology|Greek]] and [[Roman mythology]], '''Iapyx''' (from [[Ancient Greek|Greek]] Ἰάπυξ, ''gen''.: Ίάπυγος), ''Iapux'' or ''Iapis'' was a favourite of [[Apollo]]. The god wanted to confer upon him the gift of prophecy, the lyre, etc.; but Iapyx, wishing to prolong the life of his father, preferred the more tranquil art of healing to all the others.<ref name=Smith>{{SmithDGRBM|author=LS|article=Iapis|volume=2|page=550}}</ref> [[Virgil]]'s ''[[Aeneid]]'' (XII: 391, 402) relates that Iapyx was [[Aeneas]]'s healer during the [[Trojan War]] and then escaped to [[Italy]] after the war, founding [[Apulia]]. His descent is unclear. He was either: *a son of [[Iasus]],<ref name=Smith /> or *the son of [[Lycaon (Arcadia)|Lycaon]], which would make him the brother of Daunius and [[Peucetii|Peucetius]] (who went as leaders of a colony to Italy),<ref>Anton. Lib. 31.</ref> or *a Cretan, from whom the Cretans who migrated to Italy derived the name of [[Iapyges]], or *a son of [[Daedalus]] either: **by his wife, thus making him a full-brother of [[Icarus]];<ref>[[Harry Thurston Peck]], ''Harper's Dictionary of Classical Antiquities'' (1898), [[Servius]] ''ad Aeneidos'' iii. 332).</ref> **by another Cretan woman.<ref>Strabo vi.; Athen. xii.; Herod. vii. 170; Heyne, ad Virg. Aen. xi. 247.</ref> Iapyx is also the name of a minor Greek [[Anemoi#Minor winds|wind god]], the north-west or west-north-west wind. ==Notes== {{Reflist}} {{Greek-myth-stub}} [[Category:People of the Trojan War]] [[Category:Greek mythology]]
